question: What are the required specialization core classes for the MS in Software Engineering - Enterprise Software Technologies program?
answer: The required specialization core classes are CMPE 273 Enterprise Distributed Systems and CMPE 275 Enterprise Application Development, totaling 6 units.

question: What are the specialization choice classes for the MS in Software Engineering - Enterprise Software Technologies program?
answer: The specialization choice classes are CMPE 281 Cloud Technologies, CMPE 283 Virtualization Technologies, CMPE 285 Software Engineering Processes, CMPE 287 Software Quality Assurance and Testing, CMPE 206 Computer Network Design, CMPE 207 Network Programming and Applications, CMPE 257 Machine Learning, CMPE 258 Deep Learning, CMPE 209 Network Security, and CMPE 279 Software Security Technologies, totaling 3 units.

question: Can I take both required specialization core classes in the same semester?
answer: No, you must take both required specialization core classes, CMPE 273 and CMPE 275, which total 6 units, and cannot be taken in the same semester.

question: Can I take more than one specialization choice class in the same semester?
answer: No, you can only take one specialization choice class, which totals 3 units, in the same semester.

question: Can I take a specialization choice class that is not listed?
answer: No, you must choose from the listed specialization choice classes, CMPE 281, CMPE 283, CMPE 285, CMPE 287, CMPE 206, CMPE 207, CMPE 257, CMPE 258, CMPE 209, and CMPE 279.

question: What are the program requirements for MS in Software Engineering at SJSU?
answer: The program requirements for MS in Software Engineering at SJSU include completing 33 semester units of graduate study, meeting a competency in written English requirement, and completing 9 units of degree core courses, 9 units of required specialization courses, 6 units of elective courses, and 6 units of master's project or thesis.

question: Can students admitted prior to Fall 2020 follow the old program requirements?
answer: Yes, students admitted prior to Fall 2020 can continue to follow the course catalog published prior to Fall 2020 and follow the program requirements in effect at the time of their admission.

question: What are the changes to the program requirements for students admitted for Fall 2020 or later?
answer: The changes include an increase from 6 to 9 units for degree core classes, new classes for the Data Science specialization, reduction from 9 to 6 units for elective classes, and an increase in total required units from 30 to 33 units for the MS Software Engineering degree.

question: What are the degree core courses required for the MS in Software Engineering program?
answer: The degree core courses required are CMPE 272 (Enterprise Software Overview), CMPE 202 (Software Systems Engineering), and CMPE 255 (Data Mining).

question: What are the required specialization courses for the MS in Software Engineering program?
answer: Students must take two required specialization core classes from one of the six specializations plus one specialization choice class from one of the other five specializations.

question: Can I take elective courses from other departments?
answer: Yes, with prior advisor approval, students can take elective courses from other departments.

question: What are the culminating experience options for the MS in Software Engineering program?
answer: Students can choose to complete a Master's Project (6 units) or a Master's Thesis (6 units).

question: What is the competency in written English requirement?
answer: All graduate students are required to complete a competency in written English class as a requirement for graduation. The university catalog specifies alternate ways for meeting the competency in written English requirement.

question: Can AI students take SE courses?
answer: No, AI students are not eligible to take SE courses. However, students from other departments may be permitted to take SE courses with prior advisor approval.

question: What is the total number of units required for the MS in Software Engineering degree?
answer: The total number of units required for the MS in Software Engineering degree is 33 units.

question: Can I graduate using the Fall 2020 catalog if I was admitted prior to Fall 2020?
answer: Yes, students admitted prior to Fall 2020 may choose to graduate using the Fall 2020 catalog, but they must meet all new requirements and cannot pick a subset of the requirements.

question: What are the specialization options for the MS in Software Engineering program?
answer: The specialization options are Enterprise Software Technologies, Cloud Computing and Virtualization, Software Systems Engineering, Networking Software, Data Science, and Cybersecurity.

question: Can I take CMPE 294 or ENGR 200W to meet the competency in written English requirement?
answer: Yes, the Computer Engineering department requires that if a course must be taken to meet the competency in written English requirement, that the course must be CMPE 294 (preferred) or ENGR 200W.

question: What are the course numbers for the Master's Project and Master's Thesis courses?
answer: The course numbers for the Master's Project are CMPE 295A and CMPE 295B, and the course numbers for the Master's Thesis are CMPE 299A and CMPE 299B.

question: Can I take CMPE 295A or CMPE 299A concurrently with other courses?
answer: No, only one of the two classes can be taken concurrently with CMPE 295A or CMPE 299A, but NOT both, and cannot be taken after CMPE 295A.

question: What are the requirements for completing the Culminating Experience?
answer: The degree core and specialization core must be completed before beginning the Culminating Experience. It is advised that the specialization choice and CMPE 294/ENGR 200W be completed before taking CMPE 295A or CMPE 299A.

question: Can I take elective courses from other departments with prior advisor approval?
answer: Yes, with prior advisor approval, students can take elective courses from other departments.

question: What are the alternate ways to meet the competency in written English requirement?
answer: The university catalog specifies alternate ways for meeting the competency in written English requirement.

question: Can I take CMPE 294 or ENGR 200W to meet the competency in written English requirement?
answer: Yes, the Computer Engineering department requires that if a course must be taken to meet the competency in written English requirement, that the course must be CMPE 294 (preferred) or ENGR 200W.

question: What are the course numbers for the Master's Project and Master's Thesis courses?
answer: The course numbers for the Master's Project are CMPE 295A and CMPE 295B, and the course numbers for the Master's Thesis are CMPE 299A and CMPE 299B.

question: Can I take CMPE 295A or CMPE 299A concurrently with other courses?
answer: No, only one of the two classes can be taken concurrently with CMPE 295A or CMPE 299A, but NOT both, and cannot be taken after CMPE 295A.

question: What are the requirements for completing the Culminating Experience?
answer: The degree core and specialization core must be completed before beginning the Culminating Experience. It is advised that the specialization choice and CMPE 294/ENGR 200W be completed before taking CMPE 295A or CMPE 299A.

question: What are the university admission requirements for the MS in Artificial Intelligence program at SJSU?
answer: Candidates must meet all university admission requirements, which can be found at https://catalog.sjsu.edu/content.php?catoid=2&navoid=101.

question: Can I be admitted to the MS in Artificial Intelligence program in classified or conditionally classified standing?
answer: Yes, applicants can be admitted in either classified or conditionally classified standing. If an applicant's preparation for advanced graduate work is considered inadequate, conditions may include taking preparatory courses to meet course prerequisites or departmental requirements.

question: What are the specific requirements for acceptance by the Department of Computer Engineering?
answer: Applicants must satisfy the following requirements: an undergraduate degree in math, physics, computer science, engineering, or a closely related field, with demonstrated college-level courses in programming, data structures, algorithm design, three-semester sequence of calculus, linear algebra, and statistics; an undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher; and GRE scores (if applicable).

question: Do I need to take the GRE if my undergraduate program is not ABET-accredited?
answer: Yes, if your undergraduate program is not ABET-accredited, you are required to take the GRE with a minimum score of 305 (q+v) and 3.0 (AWA).

question: Can I waive the GRE requirement?
answer: Yes, the GRE requirement may be waived if you hold a CS/CMPE or related degree from an accredited US institution, or a graduate (MS/PhD) degree in a STEM domain. This is evaluated on a case-by-case basis. Please email [msai@sjsu.edu](mailto:msai@sjsu.edu) with your specifics.

question: What are the English-language proficiency test requirements for international applicants?
answer: International applicants must meet SJSU's minimum requirements on English-language proficiency tests, which can be found at /admissions/graduate/admission-requirements/index.php.

question: What is the minimum undergraduate GPA required for admission?
answer: The minimum undergraduate GPA required for admission is 3.0 or higher.

answer: The deadline for applying to the MS in Artificial Intelligence program varies, please check the SJSU admissions website for the most up-to-date information.

question: Can I apply to the MS in Artificial Intelligence program if I do not have a background in computer science or engineering?
answer: While a background in computer science or engineering is preferred, it is not required. However, you must demonstrate college-level courses in programming, data structures, algorithm design, three-semester sequence of calculus, linear algebra, and statistics.

question: What is the MS in Software Engineering - Cybersecurity Specialization program about?
answer: The MS in Software Engineering - Cybersecurity Specialization program is designed to provide students with hands-on experience in design, development, testing, and deployment of secure systems, as well as a solid understanding of organizational risk management and records integrity.

question: Why is cybersecurity important in today's digital world?
answer: Cybersecurity is of the highest priority for consumers, business leaders, and government officials, as fewer than 10 percent of the estimated 30,000 skilled security talent needed is currently available in the workforce.

question: What are the required specialization core classes for the MS in Software Engineering - Cybersecurity Specialization program?

question: How many units are required for the specialization choice classes?

question: What is the MS in Software Engineering program at SJSU?
answer: The MS in Software Engineering program, offered by the Department of Computer Engineering, provides students with an educational experience that builds on traditional computer science and engineering and takes an integrative approach to software engineering.

question: What are the specializations offered in the MSSE program?
answer: The MSSE program offers specializations in Enterprise Software Technologies, Cloud Computing and Virtualization, Software Systems Engineering, Data Science, Cybersecurity, and Networking Software.

question: Can students with undergraduate degrees in other engineering or science disciplines apply to the MSSE program?
answer: Yes, the MSSE program welcomes students with undergraduate degrees in other engineering or science disciplines and strong programming skills.

question: What is the class schedule like for the MSSE program?
answer: Class schedules are designed for the convenience of employed engineers who wish to pursue graduate work on a part-time basis.

question: What are the program requirements for the MSSE program?
answer: The program requirements include degree core, specialization classes, electives, and a culminating experience.

question: What are the six specializations offered in the MSSE program?
answer: The six specializations are Enterprise Software Technologies, Cloud Computing and Virtualization, Software Systems Engineering, Data Science, Cybersecurity, and Networking Software.

question: What are the program learning outcomes for the MSSE program?
answer: The program learning outcomes are: (a) demonstrate an understanding of advanced knowledge of the practice of software engineering, (b) tackle complex engineering problems and tasks, (c) demonstrate leadership and teamwork skills, (d) be aware of ethical, economic, and environmental implications, (e) advance successfully in the engineering profession, and (f) communicate effectively.

question: Can AI students take SE courses?
answer: No, AI students are not eligible to take SE courses, as the program is designed for students with a strong foundation in computer science and engineering.

question: What are the core courses required for the MSAI program at SJSU?
answer: The core courses required for the MSAI program at SJSU are CMPE 252 - Artificial Intelligence and Data Engineering (3 units), CMPE 257 - Machine Learning (3 units), and ISE 201 - Math Foundations for Decision and Data Sciences (3 units).

question: How many units are required for the Specialization Courses in the MSAI program?
answer: Students must complete at least 6 units from the same specialization, which can be either Data Science or Autonomous Systems.

question: What are the courses required for the Data Science specialization in the MSAI program?
answer: The courses required for the Data Science specialization are CMPE 255 - Data Mining (3 units), CMPE 256 - Advanced Data Mining (3 units), and CMPE 259 - Natural Language Processing (3 units).

question: Can I take courses from both Area A and Area B for the Elective Courses in the MSAI program?
answer: Yes, students can select 3 courses (9 units) from the list below, with at least 3 units from Area A and the remaining 6 units from either Area A or Area B.

question: What is the Graduate Writing Requirement for the MSAI program at SJSU?
answer: Students must pass the Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement (GWAR) by completing CMPE 294 - Computer Engineering Seminar (3 units).

question: What are the options for the Culminating Experience in the MSAI program?
answer: Students must complete one of the following culminating experiences: a master's thesis or a master's project, which consists of CMPE 299A - Master's Thesis I (3 units), CMPE 299B - Master's Thesis II (3 units), CMPE 295A - Master's Project I (3 units), or CMPE 295B - Master's Project II (3 units).

question: Can AI students take SE courses, and vice versa?

question: What are the requirements for a master's thesis in the MSAI program?
answer: A master's thesis includes original research on a topic approved by the thesis committee and must meet university requirements as stipulated in the SJSU Master's Thesis and Doctoral Dissertation Guidelines.

question: Can I choose my own topic for the master's project in the MSAI program?
answer: Yes, students can choose their own topic for the master's project, but it must be approved by the Graduate Advisor and the advisor.

question: What is the Networking Software specialization in the MS in Software Engineering program?
answer: The Networking Software specialization provides a unique opportunity for software engineers to learn the fundamentals and design, development, and implementation of networking and distributed systems. It focuses on network architecture, transport and application layer protocols, network programming and analysis, and includes advanced topics in network security, multimedia networking, and more.

question: What are the required specialization core courses for the Networking Software specialization?
answer: The required specialization core courses are CMPE 206: Computer Network Design and CMPE 207: Network Programming and Applications, which are both 3-unit courses.

question: What are the specialization choice courses for the Networking Software specialization?
answer: The specialization choice courses are CMPE 273: Enterprise Distributed Systems, CMPE 275: Enterprise Application Development, CMPE 281: Cloud Technologies, CMPE 283: Virtualization Technologies, CMPE 285: Software Engineering Processes, CMPE 287: Software Quality Assurance and Testing, CMPE 257: Machine Learning, CMPE 258: Deep Learning, CMPE 209: Network Security, and CMPE 279: Software Security Technologies.

question: How many units are required for the specialization choice courses?
answer: The specialization choice courses are 3 units each.

question: Can I take more than one specialization choice course?
answer: No, you can only take one specialization choice course.

question: Are there any prerequisites for the specialization core courses?
answer: Yes, CMPE 206: Computer Network Design requires CMPE 105: Introduction to Computer Networks, and CMPE 207: Network Programming and Applications requires CMPE 206: Computer Network Design.

question: Can I take the specialization core courses before taking the prerequisite courses?
answer: No, you must take the prerequisite courses before taking the specialization core courses.

answer: Yes, but you must meet the transfer credit requirements and have the credits approved by the department.

answer: Yes, but you must meet the prerequisites and admission requirements for the course, and check with the department for any specific requirements or restrictions.

answer: Yes, but you must meet the prerequisites and admission requirements for the course, and check with the department for any specific requirements or restrictions.

answer: The typical duration of the specialization is 2 years, but it may vary depending on your course load and other factors.

question: What is the purpose of the Graduate FAQ at SJSU?
answer: The Graduate FAQ is a resource for current and new graduate students at SJSU, providing an easy-to-use guide to answer common questions about graduate studies.

question: What are the six sections of the Graduate FAQ?
answer: The six sections of the Graduate FAQ are: General, Admissions, Academic Planning/Enrollment, Advancement to Candidacy, Jobs/Internships, and Culminating Experience.

question: Is my program a STEM program?
answer: Yes, all graduate programs in the College of Engineering are considered STEM programs.

question: Who should I contact for Visa and residency related questions?
answer: You should contact the ISSS Office, either virtually or in person, for any questions related to your student visa, other visa status, or compliance with immigration regulations.

question: What is Conditional Classification?
answer: Conditional Classification refers to your admission standing at SJSU, meaning you have not satisfied all the required conditions for admission. You are not allowed to take more than 12 units of graduate courses until the conditions are satisfied.

question: What is Classified status?
answer: Classified status indicates that you have satisfied all of the conditions of admission.

question: Are there test requirements for admission?
answer: It depends on the program you are applying to. Please check the GAPE website for test requirements by College and program.

question: Can I request a waiver to take the prerequisite courses in my admission letter?
answer: No, Conditional admission requires that your conditions are satisfied. If you have any prior coursework that might be similar and/or have any questions about your conditions, please contact your program advisor to receive guidance.

question: What are the tuition fees?
answer: Tuition fees and other fees for graduate students can be found under the Bursar's Office website.

question: I have questions about an admission deferral. Who should I contact?
answer: You should contact the Admissions' Office for questions about admission deferral to a graduate program.

question: I have been admitted and have questions about the next steps. Where can I find the information?
answer: You can find the steps to enrollment and who to contact if you have questions on the Admissions' Office website.

question: Does the Department of Aviation and Technology offer a graduate program?
answer: Yes, it is currently called MS in Quality Assurance, but there is a plan to rename it to MS in Engineering Technology in the near future.

question: I am a foreign student and just got admitted. What courses should I take?
answer: You should attend the New Student Orientation, which is generally scheduled at the beginning of a semester. You will be notified by your program advisor via email, detailing the schedule and place of the meeting.

question: Can I register for more than 4 courses per semester?
answer: No, please follow the Registrar's Office guidelines for maximum units allowed. Additionally, the CMPE Department has a policy that limits enrollment for its graduate students at 12 units maximum per semester.

question: Where can I get the permission number? How do you know the instructor's name?
answer: Permission numbers for each course are assigned to course instructors. You will be able to see the course instructor's name under the MySJSU portal about two to three weeks before each semester starts or earlier.

question: How do I enroll in a course?
answer: You can enroll via MySJSU during advance registration. The Registrar's Office has a tutorial on how to add a course.

question: How do I drop a course?
answer: You can drop a course by using the 'drop' tab in MySJSU. You can check the steps on the Registrar's Office website.

question: It is almost the first day of the semester and I am trying to enroll but I get an error message. Why?
answer: You might be trying to enroll during the two days of registration closed prior to the start of the semester. Please check the Registrar's Office calendar to confirm.

question: Will I get a refund if I drop the course?
answer: To learn more about the refund policy, please check the Bursar's Office website. If you are taking a course during summer session, information about refund and drop deadlines can also be found on the summer session calendar.

question: Do I need advising every semester in order to register for classes?
answer: It depends on the program. Some programs place an advising hold that requires you to meet with your program advisor every term, while other programs require this meeting only from students who are on academic probation.

question: What is the Graduate Writing Assessment Requirement (GWAR)?
answer: Please see the university catalog for information regarding the GWAR.

question: Where can I get the candidacy form?
answer: You may obtain the Candidacy form from the GAPE forms site.

question: When should I file for Candidacy?
answer: You will need to be in classified status in your program, have earned at least 9 units of letter-graded courses, have fulfilled the GWAR, and be in good standing to file your advancement to candidacy petition.

question: What if I filed for Candidacy and want to change one of the courses listed on the approved Candidacy Form?
answer: You will need to file a Request for Course Substitution to substitute a core or an elective course listed on the candidacy form.

question: Am I eligible to work for 40 hours a week during my Fall & Spring semester?
answer: No, internship work during the Fall and Spring semesters is limited to 20 hours per week maximum for international students via the Curricular Practical Training (CPT) program.

question: Can I work both a part-time on-campus job and an off-campus full-time job together?
answer: No, full-time work for international students on CPT is allowed during the summer term. You can also work on campus during that time of the year if your schedule allows.

question: When can be the last day for an internship?
answer: Please be aware of the authorized window for CPT for each term by consulting the CPT webpage from the ISSS Office.

question: What is Culminating Experience?
answer: Your culminating experience is a project or a thesis at the graduate level. A Culminating Experience Form is required by the university to show that you have met the necessary skills to obtain an MS degree.

question: What is the MS in Software Engineering - Software Systems Engineering Specialization?
answer: The MS in Software Engineering - Software Systems Engineering Specialization provides current and future software professionals with the essential skills and real-world knowledge to succeed in the software engineering field. It offers an education in the fundamentals of software engineering and an in-depth exposure to the latest technologies and trends in software development processes, methodologies, and tools.

answer: The specialization core classes require 6 units, which means students must take both CMPE 285 and CMPE 287.

question: How many units are required for the specialization choice classes?
answer: The specialization choice classes require 3 units, which means students must take one of the listed classes.

answer: No, students can only take one specialization choice class, which is 3 units.
